title: West academic and academy chain head to join House of Lords
text:
West academic and academy chain head to join House of Lords By WMNKLangston | Posted: October 26, 2015 By Kate Langston West academic and academy chain head to join House of Lords X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
The head of a successful Cornish academy chain is among the latest wave of politicians, academics and clergymen selected to join the 800-strong House of Lords. 
Professor Mary Watkins, who chairs the board of the Acorn Academy Cornwall Multi-Academy Trust, will bring expertise from a background in nursing to the role, which will see her serve as a cross-bench peer. 
She will also bring experience from her time as a lecturer and board member at Plymouth University, and says she will use the position to “champion” those in need. 
“I am honoured by this appointment,” she said. “Throughout my career I have been driven by the desire to support those most in need and to instil that ethos in my students. 
“I am truly humbled to be made a member of the House of Lords and I will use my role to continue championing those values.” 
Prof Watkins became chairman of the Acorn Academy trust board in 2014. Since it was founded in 2013, the group has seen Ofsted ratings of “good” and “outstanding” across its affiliated schools 
She is also a board member and emeritus professor of healthcare at Plymouth University, and has previously held positions as dean of health and deputy vice-chancellor. 
Natalie-Jane Macdonald, chief executive of Acorn care and education, said the group was “thrilled” prof. Watkin’s hard work “and continued support for people in need” had been recognised. 
“Mary has done great work for the children and young people at Acorn Academy Cornwall and we are confident she will be a fantastic voice for the health, social care and education sectors in the House of Lords,” she said. 
Professor David Coslett, interim vice-chancellor at Plymouth University added: “We are delighted that Mary has been honoured for her life’s work in nursing and education. 
“She has made an invaluable contribution, not just to this university, but to the region and nationally, particularly in the sphere of nursing education.” 
Other new appointments to the growing second chamber include former MP William Hague, entrepreneur Michelle Mone and Big Issue founder John Bird. 
Prof Watkins will join fellow Westcountry peers such as Lord Tyler, Lord Berkeley, Baroness Jolly and Lord Arran.
